Matthew

Just thought I'd start a thread to pose questions of biogeography to creationists. Here's a brief start.
 
 1. Why is the native mammalian fauna of Australia dominated by marsupials, and why do only a few marsupials live anywhere else? 
 
 2. Why are there no native mammals at all in New Zealand? -- Except of course, for a handful of bats....
 
 3. Why are there no frogs or toads on oceanic islands? There is a single exception -- Fiji -- and that's interesting in its own right. But the habitat on many islands is equally ideal for our hopping amphibious friends. So what gives?
 
 4. Why are there no lemurs in Africa, but no monkeys in Madagascar? Again, plenty of suitable habitat on both sides of the channel. So why the difference?
 
 5. Why are there no penguins at the North Pole, and no polar bears at the South? There are seals at both ends of the earth. So why not penguins and polar bears?
 
 Anyone else, please feel free to add to this list. Enjoy!
MrWriteLA

Anyone else, please feel free to add to this list. Enjoy!

I'm not sure if this is as relevant to the topic as one might expect, but since my family is from this place, I like to do some advertising about Reunion Island.
 
 As you may know, this volcanic island is quite close to Mauritius and Madagascar, but its fauna is not the same. My own favourite animal is the chameleon, and I also like the variety of beautiful spiders you can find there.
 
 Reunion island : Fauna in the island - Reunion?s animal life

Interesting question. I always wondered why no snakes in Hawaii
Databed

I like Hawaii, an Island far from any other land that recently popped up from the ocean floor. You would expect that land animals would be rare there. Is it any surprise that the only native species to Hawaii are insects, birds, sea animals and plants? A little surprising that there are no snakes since snakes can swim and many are ocean going, but I think they stick to the reefs and shorelines. Almost any other animal present there was brought in by settlers.
Matthew

Interesting question. I always wondered why no snakes in Hawaii

 
 Good one!
 
 And sadly, the example of Guam shows all too well what can happen when snakes do arrive on oceanic islands from which they've been previously absent....
Matthew

I'm not sure if this is as relevant to the topic as one might expect, but since my family is from this place, I like to do some advertising about Reunion Island.

 
 Actually, it's quite relevant! Islands are biogeographical marvels, with very high rates of endemism. And their native flora and fauna tend to be closely related to species from the nearest continent. Coincidence? I think not.
Easyrider

Good one!
 
 And sadly, the example of Guam shows all too well what can happen when snakes do arrive on oceanic islands from which they've been previously absent....

 
 The exact date and mode of transportation for the brown Treesnake's arrival on Guam cannot be conclusively identified, but it was most likely shipped to Guam as a stowaway in military cargo from the Papua New Guinea area during the post World War II years. As the U.S. Pacific Headquarters was transferred to Guam during and immediately after the war, U.S. military equipment and salvaged war material that had been in use at the military bases in the Admiralty Islands of northern Papua New Guinea were shipped back to the permanent bases and scrap metal processors on Guam. Additional support for this origination site is based on the characteristics of the snakes on Guam. Depending on the area it inhabits, the colors and scale patterns of the brown Treesnake vary. The snakes on Guam are most similar to those of the Admiralty Island group.
 
 History of The Brown Tree Snake Invasion on Guam
 
 Jesus is God and Creator!
Matthew

History of The Brown Tree Snake Invasion on Guam

 
 A fine link. More important in terms of what I was saying are paragraphs 4 and 5 from the link:
 
 
The disappearance of birds on the island followed the advancing high densities of snakes. By 1963, several formerly abundant species of native birds had disappeared from the central part of the island where snakes were most populous. By the late 1960s, birds had begun to decline in the central and southern parts of the island and remained abundant only in isolated patches of forest on the northern end of the island. Snakes began affecting the birds in the north-central and extreme northern parts of the island in the 1970s, and most native forest species were virtually extinct when they were listed as threatened or endangered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in 1984. The species of birds remaining on Guam are extremely patchy in distribution, occurring only in special habitats where some protection from snakes exists.
 
 At present, even small mammals are extremely rare in most forested habitats of Guam. Predation by the brown Treesnake is the most likely primary factor preventing recruitment to the single population of native Mariana fruit bats remaining on Guam. Lizard densities, particularly of introduced species with high reproductive rates, remain high, supporting the snake population. Although larger snakes are showing signs of stress, exhibited by low fat reserves, the ability to shift from birds to rodents or lizards has enabled the snake to reach and maintain extraordinarily high densities of as many as 13,000 per square mile. This is higher than snake densities in the rainforests of the Amazon Basin of Ecuador where 51 different snake species occupy the same habitat.

 
 Introduce a species into someplace it doesn't belong, and all manner of ecological havoc ensues.
 
 In any event, one wonders: Guam is obviously a great place for snakes to make a living -- so why weren't there any snakes there already?...

Just thought I'd start a thread to pose questions of biogeography to creationists. Here's a brief start.

 Well since there are no comers I thought I would just help our local creationist out, don't worry I have the handbook.
 
 
1. Why is the native mammalian fauna of Australia dominated by marsupials, and why do only a few marsupials live anywhere else? 

 because God got tired of doing the same thing
 
 
2. Why are there no native mammals at all in New Zealand? -- Except of course, for a handful of bats....

 God wanted a terrarium
 
 
3. Why are there no frogs or toads on oceanic islands? There is a single exception -- Fiji -- and that's interesting in its own right. But the habitat on many islands is equally ideal for our hopping amphibious friends. So what gives?

 Frogs are ugly, and christian families need to be happy on their vacations
 
 
4. Why are there no lemurs in Africa, but no monkeys in Madagascar? Again, plenty of suitable habitat on both sides of the channel. So why the difference?

 God wanted the explorers of Madagascar to find something new and special
 
 
5. Why are there no penguins at the North Pole, and no polar bears at the South? There are seals at both ends of the earth. So why not penguins and polar bears?

 Santa clause said he liked penguins but then he committed the sin of gluttony (it was cookies.... mid-Christmas-night) and so God got rid of all the penguins in the north pole, and put the most ferocious white bears up there so Santa would have to stay fit to protect himself.
 
 and of course for snakes in Ireland (I am not making this up) saint Patrick drove them away.
